Eingeladen ist jeder, der Lust und Zeit hat, unabhängig vom fachlichen Hintergrund, von Entwickler, Berater, Projekt Manager, Basis Administrator bis hin zum Endanwender. Im Mittelpunkt steht ein lockerer fachlicher Austausch rund um SAP-Themen über Unternehmensgrenzen hinweg.

entry.title: Re: Field Selection for RFQ Document (Ext. Sourcing Req.)...
entry.content:
Hello @sans16 

Thank you for your question.

You can consult the following references for further details.

App Extensibility: Manage RFQs, Service Procurement, Field Selection, Processing of Field Selection String & Integration with SAP Ariba

Based on your description, it seems your client’s requirement is to adjust mandatory and optional fields on the RFQ creation screen in public cloud. Specifically, to make some standard fields optional and others mandatory on sourcing responsibility between s4H and Ariba.

To summarise, in public cloud, the field control for purchasing documents such as RFQ, Purchase Order etc, is pre-delivered by SAP and you cannot change them through direct customizing which you can in private cloud and on-premise. The configuration node Field Selection is not exposed as an SSCUI in public cloud. However, there are some limited clean-core alternatives you can consider:

  1. First is to use Adapt UI to hide fields that your S4H users don’t need to maintain manually. While you cannot change the mandatory logic, you can surely hide unnecessary fields for internal users. You can achieve this by:

Opening your Manage RFQ app --> User Actions --> Adapt UI. Select a field --> Choose Hide Field --> Save as New Variant.

  1. Second option is to use BadIs for field validation by using Custom Logic app for limited field validation. Implement MM_PUR_RFQ_CHECK. You can create custom validation logic to enforce mandatory entry or allow optional entry based on your conditions. An example would be if external sourcing=true, then skip validation.
  2. Third option is for the Field relevance to follow the Ariba sourcing templates instead of S4H field setting if your business process is managed by Ariba external sourcing. Alos in the case mandatory fields are controlled in Ariba configuration.
  3. Final option is for you to raise a Feature Request if needed with SAP

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to connect SAP PO running over netweaver 7.50 with OpenText XML Adapter
entry.content:
Introduction

In today's digital landscape, enterprises rely heavily on seamless integration between platforms to maintain agility, optimize operations, and enhance digital transformation initiatives. SAP Process Orchestration (SAP PO) is a comprehensive integration software that enables the synchronization of processes and data across numerous SAP and non-SAP applications. One such integration possibility involves connecting SAP PO with OpenText's SOAP API to facilitate efficient document management capabilities.

OpenText is a leading enterprise information management company known for its robust solutions, including its SOAP API which provides functionalities for document management. Integrating SAP PO with OpenText's SOAP API allows organizations to achieve a streamlined connection between their business processes and their document management systems, thereby enhancing access to vital information and documents.

Before embarking on this integration journey, several key considerations must be addressed, including authentication mechanisms, message format mapping, and error handling. Given that SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol) relies on XML-based messaging protocols, mastering these elements is critical for a successful and secure integration. This article will guide you through the essential steps for establish a secure connection to OpenText's SOAP API and offer insights into how to authenticate users and manage documents effectively.

Goal

The goal of this article is to guide enterprises on connecting a legacy system to OpenText using SAP PO, and to generate a single endpoint that encapsulates multiple requests to different services exposed by OpenText. By achieving this, organizations can streamline their document management processes, reduce complexity, and enhance the efficiency of their operations.

 

The first step in order to achieve the integration of both systems will be to Establishing a secure and reliable connection between SAP PO and OpenText's SOAP API requires robust authentication mechanisms.

In this case we will delve into the basic authentication. Understanding this methodology is crucial for safeguarding your data and ensuring authorized access only.

Once authenticated, the core of the integration lies in the consumption of document management features offered by the OpenText SOAP API. This section offers a step-by-step guide on how to configure SAP PO to interact with OpenText's document management functionalities.

To simplify, the basic architecture will be structured this way.

A single interface is presented to the legacy system, which is then divided within SAP PI to engage multiple interfaces based on a custom tag referred to as method.

Step 1.

Generate a single data type with a common structure for the services that will be consolidated on one.

The following Data Type will be used as the request

And this Data Type will be used for the response

Transformation process involve several use of graphical mapping and XSLT transformations in order to achieve the goal to get a single entry point for all the exposed services, with the graphical mappings allowing to include transformations and validations in order to detect the data type received 

Step 2 

Define the graphical message mappings for request and response, one for each inbound service interface defined.

Step 3

At the response graphical mapping, add custom java functions in order to identify and set the data type of the values that are returning, the custom functions must to be embedded inside the mapping and be called as custom functions.

This custom function receive 5 entry parameters that are returned by the opentext get node method, evaluate the data type of the value and return a single text with the description of the type, the goal of this is reduce the complexity of the logic at the legacy system.

Here is the Java code of the custom function

 

at also another custom function was developed to validate the data type of any value returned at the Values tag

Step 4

Build the XSLT transformations in order to adapt the structure to the opentext services, this will add the corresponding namespaces, eliminate non necessary tags and generate the parents when will be need it.

Step 5.

Build the operation mapping that will be in charge of call sequentially the graphical message mapping and the XSLT transformations, this operation mapping will have one step for request and another for response considering the process defined as Synchronous.

Request side will at first call the graphical mapping and at second will use the XSLT transformation

The response side will call the XSLT transformation that will adapt the structure, then add the namespace and at last use the graphical mapping where the custom java functions are located

Once all the steps are done and the iFlow is created and deployed the service could be tested using SOAP UI.

 

Conclusion

This approach allow to generate a single endpoint to consume some specific methods of the Opentext implementation, allowing to get an homogeneous structure at response, but will require some work if new methods will be implemented, at also the architecture could be considered slightly coupled since maintenance could be required as well but not frequently.

The current architecture could face several challenges to be migrated to SAP Integration Suite running over BTP

entry.title: Complete Guide: Setting Up CAP Plugin for Advanced Event Mesh with OAuth Authentication
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog is the result of the steps taken to successfully use the official CAP plugin for Advanced Event Mesh. It took some time to set it up through a series of trial-and-error approaches. I knew I couldn't keep everything in mind, so initially this content was intended to be the README.md file of the resulting repository.

There is plenty of material in the Community that speaks about the setup steps of the prerequisites, including a dedicated chapter in the official SAP Help:

  • Securing SAP Advanced Event Mesh: OAuth Configuration and SEMP API Integration by Carlos Roggan
  • Securing Advanced Event Mesh: Comprehensive Guide to OAuth Configuration in Broker Manager by Carlos Roggan
  • SAP Cloud Integration: Advanced Event Mesh Adapter series, also by Carlos Roggan
  • Setup CAP Plugin from the official documentation

This blog ties all these pieces together into a single end-to-end guide.

Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have:

  • An active subscription of Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), or a subaccount in which you have AEM entitlement
  • Administrative access to Identity Authentication Services (IAS)
  • Cloud Foundry CLI installed and configured
  • A REST client (Postman, Hoppscotch, Bruno, or cURL)
  • CAP development environment set up

Scope of This Guide

Important: This guide covers Authentication only, not Authorization, and specifically for the CAP Plugin. All other use cases are already covered in the referenced blogs by Carlos Roggan.

Values Reference Guide

Throughout this guide, we'll collect several values that will be reused multiple times. Values highlighted in green are critical configuration values you'll need to reference later. Keep them in a secure note-taking application as you progress through the steps.

 

SAP Identity Authentication Services

The CAP plugin requires OAuth-based access to work. We need an Identity Provider capable of generating JWT tokens for connecting to the AEM Service. For this, we'll use Identity Authentication Services (IAS).

Create an OIDC Application

Navigate to the IAS Administration console, then select the Application & Resources menu entry:

  • Select Create from the header of the left-side navigation list
  • Fill in the following attributes:
    • Application Name: Choose a descriptive name
    • Type: Set to SAP BTP Solution
    • Protocol Type: Set to OpenID Connect
  • Select Create

The Application Details page opens. Complete these two configuration steps:

Configure OpenID Connect

  • Select the OpenID Connect Configuration list entry
    • Enter a configuration name (can be any descriptive name), then select Save
    • Scroll down to the Grant Types section
    • Ensure that Client Credentials, JWT Bearer, and Refresh Token are toggled On
    • You may enable other options, but they are not required for this guide

Create Client Credentials

  • Scroll down to Client Authentication and select this list entry
  • Navigate to the Secrets section and select Add
  • This creates a dedicated Client ID and corresponding Client Secret for JWT token generation:
    • Enter a meaningful name for the secret
    • Select the OIDC Scopes: at minimum, choose OpenID
    • Select Save

⚠️CRITICAL: Copy the Client ID and Client Secret from the pop-up immediately. The secret cannot be retrieved later—if lost, you'll need to generate a new one.

Collect IAS Configuration Values

Before proceeding to AEM configuration, collect these values. Fields in green are required for creating the OAuth Profile in the Broker Manager:

  • Client ID (from the previous step)
  • Client Secret (from the previous step)
  • OIDC Issuer Information:
    • Navigate to Application & Resources → Tenant Settings → Single Sign-On → OpenID Connect Configuration
    • Copy the URL value from the Issuer section: this is your Issuer Identifier
    • Select the Show Discovery Endpoint button
    • Copy the URL from the browser window that opens: this is your Discovery Endpoint

Test Token Generation

Let's verify that the client credentials can successfully generate JWT tokens.

Using your preferred REST client (Postman, Hoppscotch, Bruno, or cURL), execute the following request:

curl -X POST "https://youriastenant/oauth2/token" \
-H "Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded" \
-d "grant_type=client_credentials" \
-d "client_id=" \
-d "client_secret=" \
-d "token_format=jwt"

A successful request returns HTTP 200 with a response similar to:

{
  "access_token": "eyJqa3UiOiJodHRwczovL2FtY21nYmpwZS5hY2NvdW50cy5jbG91ZC5zYXAvb2F1dGgyL2NlcnRzIiwia2lkIjoiTjdvNU1aSW5jR1ltelIzcmtNaVlTYkZWcW1zIiwiYWxnIjoiUlMyNTYifQ..NvjwTzyfua785jqLWGWkDP7quLhFMzVhundvMjitkOWVr3snb7pL0Z3nHNvHy0qYo6DadIpSHUVA3pchAR0xvhlXKgIRhX4hMRp2T1JzNTm9sVV7Mv92Bxt3Q990-vQh3DhHZj_pkqvDMflo8hpcobgXwQyy0sXGPI7GM_BChQ74BoqiR9m28jvVKxwtJh18d_Gc4d1J3hJzUxs2m4Gec-Lose7B63WkfwXeeprMW_RLdOCKvOGfuWbMQBPJWjJnfr4ayE3Uq2wEtFZEylFvQjMDsd1otO-_ZRmZwbs76DHf5TD2CBH0Up9LwKH8Ww87gcn9T8ULSbiV4ijQenaa2g",
  "token_type": "Bearer",
  "expires_in": 3600
}

Verify Token Contents

Copy the value of the access_token property and navigate to jwt.io. Paste the token value in the left-hand textarea (Encoded section), replacing the default values. You should see the decoded token on the right:

{
  "sub": "b52ed1e3-125c-4eb5-ba95-48de30102850",
  "aud": "b52ed1e3-125c-4eb5-ba95-48de30102850",
  "azp": "b52ed1e3-125c-4eb5-ba95-48de30102850",
  "iss": "https://amcmgbjpe.accounts.cloud.sap",
  "azpacr": "1",
  "exp": 1762800894,
  "iat": 1762797294,
  "jti": "5bfccdab-9902-483b-83e6-50ddd820353f"
}

Note that the sub value matches your Client ID and the iss value is your Identity Authentication tenant (the token issuer).

With IAS successfully configured to generate JWT tokens, we're ready to configure AEM to accept these tokens for authentication.

 

SAP Advanced Event Mesh

(Optional) Create a Service Broker

Skip this step if you already have a Service Broker you'd like to use.

Open the AEM Cluster Manager and select the Create Service button on the Services page. You'll be prompted to provide the following details:

  • Service Name: Choose a descriptive name
  • Cloud Provider: Select your preferred provider (e.g., AWS)
  • Region: Choose the region nearest to you (e.g., eu-south-1)
  • Version: Keep the default or specify a version
  • Service Type: For this tutorial, Developer (Broker-100) is sufficient
  • Advanced Connection Options:
    • Expand this section and review the Message VPN Name
    • It's auto-generated from your Service Name, but you can customize it
    • Choose something memorable—you'll need this value frequently

Select Create Service at the bottom right to continue.

Service Broker Details

Create the OAuth Profile for the Broker Manager

Navigate to the Cluster Manager and open your Service Broker.

In the top navigation menu, select Manage, then select the Access Control link in the left-hand navigation menu under Broker Manager Quick Links.

Service Management

The Access Control page opens to the Client Authentication → Settings sub-section.

Select OAuth Profile (located after the Settings sub-section). Here we'll create a new OAuth Profile and set it as the default.

OAuth Profile

Select "+ OAuth Profile" in the top-right corner and provide a profile name (e.g., IAS_BASED_ACCESS).

Configure OAuth Profile Attributes

In the configuration screen, fill in the following attributes using the green-highlighted values we collected from IAS:

AttributeValueNotes
EnabledtrueEnable the profile
OAuth Client IDClient IDFrom IAS Application
OAuth Client Secret
(click Change OAuth Client Secret)		Client SecretFrom IAS Application
OAuth RoleResource ServerAEM acts as resource server
Disconnect on Token ExpirationtrueRecommended for security
Issuer IdentifierIssuer IdentifierFrom IAS Tenant Settings
Discovery EndpointDiscovery EndpointFrom IAS Tenant Settings
Parse Access TokentrueRequired for validation
Validate Access Token AudiencetrueValidates token audience
Required AudienceClient IDFrom IAS Application
Validate Access Token IssuertrueValidates token issuer
Required IssuerIssuer IdentifierFrom IAS Tenant Settings
Validate Access Token ScopefalseNot required for this setup
Validate Access Token TypefalseNot required for this setup

Save the profile.

Create a Client Username

This step is essential for AEM to recognize your Client ID as a valid username. It's simple but easy to forget.

Navigate back to the Access Control page, then select Client Usernames in the main navigation menu:

Client Usernames

Select "+ Client Username" and in the pop-up that appears, enter your Client ID. In the configuration page that opens, set:

AttributeValueNotes
EnabledtrueEnable the client
Client ProfiledefaultUse default profile
ACL ProfiledefaultUse default ACL
Guaranteed Endpoint Permission Override(leave default)No override needed
Subscription ManagertrueAllow subscription management

Save the Client Username.

Set the Default OAuth Profile

Navigate to Client Authentication → Settings, scroll down to the OAuth Authentication setting, and toggle it On. From the drop-down menu, select the profile we just created (e.g., IAS_BASED_ACCESS) as the Default Profile Name:

OAuth Authentication default profile

We're done with the UI-based configuration in AEM! Next, we'll configure the SEMP API.

Add the OAuth Profile to the SEMP API

The CAP plugin uses the SEMP (Solace Element Management Protocol) API to manage broker elements. It requires an OAuth Configuration on the SEMP side as well.

We can reuse the values configured in the Broker Manager, but we must perform these changes using the Solace SEMP REST API (no UI is available).

The SEMP API endpoints are visible from Cluster Manager → Service Details under the Connect section. Scroll down to Connect with Management Tools:

SEMP

To create the OAuth Profile initially, we need:

  • A personal access token for authentication
  • Your Service technical ID
  • The Solace Cloud API endpoint

Create a Personal Access Token

From the Cluster Manager page, select the User icon at the bottom left, then select Token Management.

Select Create Token in the top-right corner. Provide a token name and select the required scopes. For experimentation, you can select all scopes. For more information, see the Solace API documentation.

Select Create Token at the bottom right and copy the generated token immediately—you won't be able to view it again.

Get the Service Technical ID

Navigate to Cluster Manager → Service Details for your service and scroll down to the Availability and Versioning section. Copy the Service ID.

Call the Solace Cloud API

Using your preferred REST client, execute the following request. Replace the placeholders in the JSON payload:

AttributeValue
clientIdClient ID
clientSecretClient Secret
endpointDiscoveryDiscovery Endpoint
oauthProfileNameChoose a unique profile name (e.g., "clientcredentials_ias")
resourceServerRequiredIssuerIssuer Identifier
resourceServerRequiredAudienceClient ID

Replace <your_service_id> with your Service technical ID and <your_PAT_Token> with your Personal Access Token:

curl --request POST \
--url https://api.solace.cloud/api/v2/missionControl/eventBrokerServices/your_service_id/broker/SEMP/v2/config/oauthProfiles \
--header 'Authorization: Bearer your_pat_token' \
--header 'content-type: application/json' \
--data '{
  "clientId": "Client ID",
  "clientSecret": "Client Secret",
  "defaultGlobalAccessLevel": "read-only",
  "defaultMsgVpnAccessLevel": "read-write",
  "enabled": true,
  "endpointDiscovery": "Discovery Endpoint",
  "issuer": "Issuer",
  "oauthProfileName": "clientcredentials_ias",
  "oauthRole": "resource-server",
  "resourceServerParseAccessTokenEnabled": false,
  "resourceServerValidateIssuerEnabled": true,
  "resourceServerRequiredIssuer": "Issuer",
  "resourceServerValidateAudienceEnabled": true,
  "resourceServerRequiredAudience": "Client ID",
  "resourceServerValidateTypeEnabled": true,
  "resourceServerRequiredType": "JWT",
  "resourceServerValidateScopeEnabled": false,
  "sempEnabled": true
}'

A successful request returns HTTP 200 with the complete OAuth Profile definition.

⚠️Troubleshooting: If you receive an error like "Your permissions have changed," verify your Personal Access Token is correct.

Modifying the Profile

Inspect the returned JSON and verify all values. If corrections are needed, you must delete and recreate the profile (PUT/PATCH operations are not supported):

curl --request DELETE \
  --url https://api.solace.cloud/api/v2/missionControl/eventBrokerServices/your_service_id/broker/SEMP/v2/config/oauthProfiles/ \
  --header 'Authorization: Bearer your_pat_token'

Then execute the POST request again with corrected values. Repeat as needed until the configuration is correct.

Test the SEMP Configuration

Let's verify the new OAuth Configuration in SEMP works correctly.

We'll obtain an access token from IAS and use it to invoke the SEMP API. This time, we'll use your cluster's SEMP API endpoint (not the global Solace Cloud API).

Replace the placeholder values in the commands below:

# Get IAS Token:
curl --request POST \
  --url https://your_ias_tenant/oauth2/token \
  --header 'content-type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' \
  --data grant_type=client_credentials \
  --data client_id=your_client_id\
  --data response_type=token \
  --data client_secret=your_client_secret

# Call the SEMP API with the generated token:
curl --request GET \
  --url https://your_semp_endpoint:943/SEMP/v2/config/msgVpns//queues \
  --header 'Authorization: Bearer ias_generated_token'

Regardless of the JSON response content, the last call should return HTTP 200. If you receive a 401 Unauthorized error, review your OAuth Profile creation and try deleting and recreating it.

 

Integrate with CAP

We've reached the final step—creating a CAP application that connects to our Broker using OAuth authentication.

Prerequisites

Following the official documentation, we need:

  • An instance of service aem-validation-service with plan aem-validation-service-plan
  • A user-provided service (UPS) instance containing the IAS and Broker endpoint configuration

Create the AEM Validation Service

Create the service instance and service key:

cf create-service aem-validation-service aem-validation-service-plan 
cf create-service-key

Create the User-Provided Service

Important: The service must be named exactly advanced-event-mesh.

cf create-user-provided-service advanced-event-mesh -p '{
  "authentication-service": {
    "clientid": "your_IAS_Client_ID",
    "clientsecret": "your_IAS_Client_Secret",
    "tokenendpoint": "https://your_IAS_Tenant/oauth2/token"
  },
  "endpoints": {
    "advanced-event-mesh": {
      "smf_uri": "wss://yourserviceendpoint:443",
      "uri": "https://yourserviceendpoint:9443"
    }
  },
  "vpn": "your_service_vpn_name"
}'

Replace all placeholder values with your actual configuration.

Find Endpoint Values

To find values for endpoints.advanced-event-mesh:

  1. Navigate to Cluster Manager → Service Details → Connect
  2. Open the Node.js connection section

Node.Js connection params

  • Select web-messaging to get the smf_uri value
  • Select rest to get the uri value

For the vpn value, navigate to Cluster Manager → Service Details, locate the DMR Cluster section, and copy the Message VPN property.

Create the CAP Application

Initialize a new CAP application:

cds init my-aem-powered-app
cd my-aem-powered-app
npm add -js/advanced-event-mesh
npm install
cds bind aem-validation-service -2 aem-validation-service:yourkeyname --for hybrid --kind aem-validation-service
cds bind advanced-event-mesh -2 advanced-event-mesh --for hybrid --kind user-provided

Add a Service Definition

Create a service definition of your choice. This example uses a simple purchase order service:

service AdminService {
    entity PurchaseOrderHeaders as projection on db.PurchaseOrderHeader {
        *,
        items: redirected to PurchaseOrderItems,
        supplier: redirected to Suppliers,
    }
    entity PurchaseOrderItems   as projection on db.PurchaseOrderItem {
        *,
        PurchaseOrderHeader: redirected to PurchaseOrderHeaders
    };
    
    entity Suppliers            as projection on db.Supplier;
}

Configure the Advanced Event Mesh Plugin

Update your .cdsrc.json file to configure the messaging plugin:

{
    "requires": {
        "messaging": {
            "kind": "advanced-event-mesh"
        }
    }
}

Add Event Publishing Logic

Implement logic to publish events when entities are created or updated:

import cds from "@sap/cds";
const LOG = cds.log("admin-service");

export default class AdminService extends cds.ApplicationService {
    async init() {
        await super.init();

        const messaging = await cds.connect.to("messaging");
        
        this.after(["CREATE", "UPDATE"], "PurchaseOrderHeaders", async (data, req) => {
            LOG.info(`Purchase Order ${req.event === 'CREATE' ? 'Created' : 'Updated'} with ID: ${data.ID} and Name: ${data.Name}`);
            
            // Emit the event
            try {
                await messaging.emit(
                    req.event === 'CREATE' ? 
                        "cap/msg/admin/purchaseorder/created" : 
                        "cap/msg/admin/purchaseorder/updated",
                    {
                        ID: data.ID,
                        Name: data.Name,
                    },
                    { 
                        headers: { 
                            "X-Correlation-ID": req.headers["x-correlation-id"] 
                        } 
                    }
                );
            } catch (error) {
                LOG.error(`Error emitting event: ${error.message}`);
                return req.reject(500, `Failed to emit event: ${error.message}`);
            }
        });
    }
}

Run the Application

For initial testing, run the application with the messaging debug flag:

DEBUG=messaging cds watch --profile hybrid

Inspect the terminal output. If everything is configured correctly, you'll see connection logs similar to (abbreviated for brevity):

# ... initialization logs ...
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: websocket browserSupportBinaryCheck: true - WebSocket supports binaryType
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: [session-fsm=N/A] [WaitingForDNS] Creating transport session wss://yourserviceendpoint:443/
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: websocket browserSupportBinaryCheck: true - WebSocket supports binaryType
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: Connect Transport WS_BINARY
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: Establishing WebSocket transport session
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: Constructing socket
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: WebSocket is connecting
# ... [abbreviated for brevity] ...
[advanced-event-mesh] - solclientjs: Web transport receive transport event: {
  transportEventCode: 'UP_NOTICE (1)',
  infoStr: 'Connected',
  responseCode: 0,
  errorSubcode: '',
  sid: 'N/A'
}
# ... connection established logs ...
[cds] - connect to messaging > advanced-event-mesh {authentication-service: {...}, endpoints: {...}, vpn: 'yourservicename'}
# ... ready to serve requests ...

End-to-End Test

Before testing the complete flow, set up a subscriber in AEM to receive the published messages.

Connect as a Subscriber

  1. Navigate to Cluster Manager → Service Details → Try Me! section
  2. Note the Client Username and Password displayed
  3. Select Open Broker Manager

Try Me! Page

Configure the Subscriber

In the right-hand Subscriber section:

  1. Connect to the Broker (you may need to uncheck the Same as Publisher option)
  2. Once connected, scroll down to the Subscribe section
  3. Enter the topic you're publishing from CAP:
    • cap/msg/admin/purchaseorder/created
    • cap/msg/admin/purchaseorder/updated
  4. Select Subscribe

Trigger an Event

Return to your CAP application and create or update a Purchase Order entity. In the AEM Try Me! section, you should see your message appear:

Receiving message on topic

 

Troubleshooting Common Issues

401 Unauthorized on SEMP API

Symptom: SEMP API calls return 401 Unauthorized.

Solution: Verify the OAuth Profile configuration in SEMP. Delete and recreate the profile if necessary, ensuring all values match your IAS configuration.

Token Generation Fails

Symptom: Cannot generate JWT tokens from IAS.

Solution: Verify the Client ID and Client Secret are correct. Ensure the Grant Types (Client Credentials, JWT Bearer) are enabled in the OIDC configuration.

CAP Application Cannot Connect

Symptom: CAP application fails to establish WebSocket connection.

Solution: Verify the user-provided service configuration. Ensure the smf_uri and uri endpoints are correct and the VPN name matches your service. Double check if the OAuth Profile is active and set as default in the Broker Manager.

Conclusion

We covered:

  • Configuring IAS as an OAuth provider
  • Setting up OAuth profiles in AEM Broker Manager and SEMP API
  • Creating and testing a CAP application with event publishing
  • Verifying end-to-end message flow

Thank you for following this long article!

The referenced materials provide additional context and details for specific use cases. Kudos go to the respective authors.

For questions or additional support, please refer to the official SAP documentation or reach out via the SAP Community.

All the best,

Roberto.

entry.title: Top 10 takeaways #SAPTeched 2025
entry.content:
1. The "App-Data-AI" Flywheel is the Core Strategy: SAP has unified its entire strategy under a single "App-Data-AI flywheel" concept. This isn't just new marketing; it’s a fundamental organizing principle.

The idea is that best-in-class applications (like S/4HANA, SuccessFactors) own business critical transactional data that are key to running the day-to-day of a business. For Insights, The data they generate is leveraged via a harmonized, managed, and governed data layer - the SAP Business Data Cloud.  This clean, context-rich data then powers the new world of AI, which in turn makes the applications smarter.

SAP BTP is the engine for this flywheel, acting as the AI native foundation. This model explains why SAP is so focused on things like data connectivity and new models, that are essential for making this flywheel spin with exponential value.

Teched 1_Apps Data AI

 

 

2. SAP’s Big Bet: RPT-1, a Foundation Model for Structured Data: In what was arguably the biggest technical reveal, SAP announced SAP RPT-1 (Relational Pre-trained Transformer Model-1), it's first foundation model built specifically for structured, tabular business data.

This is a massive deal.

LLMs are great for text based language, but most business data lives in tables. Until now, solving predictive tasks (like "will this customer churn?") required a specific algorithm. For each different use case, thence you need to training hundreds of "narrow AI models."

The Promise of RPT-1 is that it is trained to act like an LLM for this types of questions to be answered on tabular data types. From test, it already outperforms typical text based large language models.

The demo of auto-completing a sales order line item was shown, as an example.

This tabular prediction, LLM style, can solve several classic prediction problems, all using one pre-trained model. This is SAP leveraging its core strength in structured data to build a new class of AI. 

Teched 2_SAP RPT-1

 

 

3. The Developer Experience: Open, Agentic, and in VS Code: The loudest applause of the day was reserved for the developers experience. 

SAP is making more open it's ABAP programming language and the fine tuned model (SAP-ABAP-1) to one's own preferred Integrated development environment (IDE), include tools actively adopting Vibe coding capabilities including Cline, Windsurf and Cursor among others. 

Teched 3_Open, Agentic and in VS Code

 

 

4. The Agentic Enterprise: From Build to Management: SAP is rolling out a comprehensive strategy for Agentic AI, from shipping out-of-the-box agents (Joule Agents) to capabilities of building custom agents with Agent Builder in Joule Studio to standardizing on rapidly adopted Agentic protocols including MCP (Model Context Protocol) and A2A (Agent to Agent Protocol).

In addition, to manage this new Agentic "workforce," the strategy connects to the Business Transformation Suite: the SAP Lean IX Agent Hub provides governance, and agent mining in SAP Signavio will trace and measure their business impact.

Teched 4_ Agentic AI

 

 

 

5. The Data Fabric Gets a boost: BDC now Connects to Snowflake: SAP is aggressively expanding its openness to the data front, adding Snowflake to the SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and announcing SAP Snowflake as a native solution extension.

This is a direct response to what joint customers have been asking for. The BDC Connect program, which already includes Databricks and Google Cloud, enables "secure zero-copy sharing." This means customers can bring their SAP data products directly to their existing data platforms without costly and complex data movement. The "SAP Snowflake Extension" takes this even further, bringing Snowflake's capabilities natively into the BDC. This pragmatic, open approach is critical for making the App-Data-AI flywheel a reality in heterogeneous customer landscapes.

Teched 5 SAP Snowflake Solution Extension

 

 

6. HANA Cloud, The AI-Native Database: SAP HANA Cloud is "the database AI was looking for,": I have to say, there was a great amount of love and vibes when this was mentioned on stage about HANA. For those not fully versed on HANA's history as a new columnar DB pioneered by Hasso Platner and Vishal Sikka - this is worthy addition to it history. 

The latest upgrade to HANA is that it now has Agentic capabilities and a massive performance boost!! what a story. 

Michael Ameling’s session highlighted that HANA is no longer just a fast in-memory database; it's a multi-modal database built for the AI era. The Knowledge Graph engine is now three times faster. But the real news is the introduction of agents inside the database. New "discovery agents" will help find data objects, and "agentic memory in HANA Cloud" will allow AI agents to "persist context across long-running sessions," enabling them to learn and remember. This makes HANA the intelligent, context-aware heart of the data layer.

Teched 6_HANA Cloud

 

 

7. Beyond the Hype: 'Benchmark Engineering' for AI: Philip Herzig introduced "benchmark engineering," a new toolset in AI Foundation to move AI from "vibe checking" to a true engineering discipline.

This is one of the most practical and important announcements for developers. Everyone struggles with "prompt engineering" and model unreliability. SAP is delivering a solution. The new suite includes an "Eval service" to test use cases across models, a "Prompt optimizer" (now GA) to automatically convert and improve prompts, a "Prompt registry," and "Model fallback." This is an "all you need tool set" that finally gives developers the rigorous controls they need to build and maintain enterprise-grade AI applications.

Teched 7_ Benchmark Engineering

 

 

8. Data Products Studio - The 'How' for the Data Fabric: If "BDC Connect" is about sharing data, the new "Data Products Studio" is about creating it. This new tool within Business Data Cloud allows data teams to visually model new data products, blend SAP and non-SAP data, and govern them in a shared domain-based catalog. This is the practical "how-to" for building the data fabric, giving teams the control to create the reusable, AI-ready data products that the rest of the new agentic platform will consume.

Teched 8_SAP Data Product Studio

 

9. Physical AI: Joule Agents Get Embodied: in a "one more thing" moment, Philip Herzig demonstrated the next frontier: bringing Joule Agents into the physical world through partnerships with robotics companies.

By using the new agentic protocols, Joule agents can now orchestrate physical robots. The demo showed a Joule agent delegating a warehouse picking task in EWM to a humanoid robot, which then identified a defective item and, with Joule's help, resolved the issue according to the business process. 

Teched 9_Physical AI

 

10. The Quantum Leap: SAP Primes for the Next Compute Era: While still on the horizon, SAP announced it is making huge leaps in quantum computing, focusing on algorithms and business processes rather than building the hardware. 

The vision is a "hybrid cloud architecture" where an SAP business process can "offload an intractable optimization problem to a quantum computer via a seamless API call."

The demo of a truck loading scenario showed how quantum can be "interwoven" into a business process, making it "as simple as flipping a switch" for the end-user. SAP is ensuring it will be ready to embed this power into the enterprise stack as soon as it's viable.

Teched 10_The Quantum Leap

entry.title: Re: How to map G/L account to Cost Center as mandatory Co...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Following the below steps to maintain the settings for account assignment type CC - Cost Center:

  1. Go to the Business Configuration work center.
  2. Go to Overview.
  3. Search for the activity Mandatory Account Assignments.
  4. Click Edit Mandatory Account Assignments for G/L Accounts.
  5. Select the respective Chart of Accounts.
  6. Filter for G/L account ABC and select the Account Assignment Type is CC - Cost Center.
    (ABC means the G/L Account number)

Best Regards,

SAP Technical Support

LOOP AT is_ee_org_ass_repl_req-org_assignment INTO ls_org_assignment.

      SELECT SINGLE sobid  FROM hrp1001 CLIENT SPECIFIED

        objid = @iv_posicion AND ( begda <= @iv_fecha AND endda >= @LV_fechaf ) AND subty = 'A012'

      IF sy-subrc = 0.
        DATA lv_sobidp TYPE plans .
        lv_sobidp = lv_sobid.
        SELECT SINGLE sobid  FROM hrp1001 
           INTO (@lv_sobid)
           WHERE objid = @LV_sobidp AND ( begda <= @iv_fecha AND endda >= @LV_fechaf ) AND otype = 'O' AND sclas = 'O'  AND subty = 'A002'.
        IF sy-subrc = 0.
          lv_orgeh2 = lv_sobid.
        ENDIF.
      ELSE.
lv_orgeh2 = iv_depart.

        EXPORTING
          act_otype      = 'O'
          act_objid      = lv_orgeh2
          act_wegid      = 'BOSSONLY' 
          act_begda      = iv_fecha
          act_endda      = iv_fechaf
        TABLES

        EXCEPTIONS
          no_plvar_found = 1
          no_entry_found = 2
          OTHERS         = 3.

      READ TABLE lt_result_tab INTO ls_result_tab WITH KEY otype = 'P'. 
*More code..

ENDLOOP

entry.title: Central Hub for Japan Tax in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Below are the key materials that you can explore to get a complete understanding of how Japan VAT will be handled in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition:

Featured Blog

A clear primer on the legal changes underpinning Japan’s Invoice Method and how it impacts tax accounting, invoicing, and reporting processes. It explains qualified invoice requirements, taxable vs. non-taxable treatment nuances, and the transition timeline, setting the stage for how SAP S/4HANA Cloud supports the reform.

Introduction to Invoice Method - Japan TAX Reform effective on October 1st 2023

After understanding the context of this legal requirement change, if you want to understand how this impact on S/4HANA Cloud System, please check:

3223860 - Japan - HEISEI 28 (FY 2016) Tax Reform - Introduction of Invoice Method (TEKIKAKU SEIKYUSH...: Explains scope, legal background, and solution coverage for the Invoice Method, including enablement guidance and impact on tax processing.

3067001 - Japan - HEISEI 28 (FY 2016) Tax Reform - Introduction of Invoice Method (TEKIKAKU SEIKYUSH....: Provides supporting details, corrections, and/or implementation clarifications complementing the core reform enablement.

Featured SAP Notes

  • 3006468 - Japan: Documentation on Japan VAT Return (SAP Document and Reporting Compliance): Central documentation entry for the Japan VAT return in SAP DRC.
  • 3351929 - Business Partner Extensions for Japan VAT - SAP for Me: Details Business Partner enhancements required for Japan VAT (e.g., registration numbers), including how to manage and validate them.
  • 3581293 - New tax codes for Japan not available: Troubleshooting guide for missing Japan tax codes.
  • 3578281 - Remarks field in Japan Withholding Tax White Returns: Clarifies behavior of the “Remarks” field in Japanese WHT white returns and guides expected data and formatting.
  • 3597702 - Error message ID_FIAA_JP_TAX074 - 'Entry for declaration key &1 and city code &2 is missing' when open Prepare Property Tax Declaration - Japan app - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Fixes “Entry for declaration key &1 and city code &2 is missing” by guiding through prerequisite data and configuration to avoid the error.
  • 3673084 - Net book value is zero for depreciation area 01 instead of 1 - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public edition: Explains why NBV might post to an unexpected area and how to correct configuration or data dependencies that lead to zero NBV in area 01.
  • 3616097 - Why Base Value is Zero, Depreciation Amount is Non-zero in Tax Area?: Resolution for depreciation shortage.

For Japan Tax Calculation Rounding, please review:

  • 80977 - Tax calc. from gross amounts, tax rounding - part 1
  • 84356 - Tax calc. from gross amounts, several lines:part 2
  • 3291943 - 'Difference Amount' in 'Tax Reconciliation Account Balance' App Caused by Rounding
  • 3662134 - Specific Rounding rule for Japan Tax Calculation in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

QnA

  • How to adjust the tax amount for Japanese yen sal... - SAP Community
  • Solved: FY23 Japan consumption tax filling obligation - SAP Community

For additional information, please review

  • Help Portal Consumption Tax | Japan.
  • Follow Tag: "japan" in "Products and Technology" - SAP Community

Stay Updated

This blog will be continually updated with the latest posts related to this topic. By following this post, you’ll receive alerts whenever new material becomes available.

If you have any ideas or topics you’d like us to discuss, please share them in the comments section below.

entry.title: Bridging SAP Commerce and SAP Finance - Enabling Online Invoice Payments in SAP B2B Self Service
entry.content:
The B2B Payment Challenge

In most B2B business operations today, the final mile of the order-to-cash process which is a invoice payment and reconciliation process remains largely manual and fragmented.

Customers receive invoices, process payments through various channels for ex: bank transfers, and business finance teams spend hours matching payments with open items in SAP ERP System.

The recent B2B payment trend studies show that nearly 50% of the B2B Invoices are paid late impacting working capital and liquidity. Even when organizations have digitized their business processes, the invoice payment and reconciliation journey often remains disconnected from the digital experience.

This is exactly where the SAP Digital Payments Add-On (DPA) brings value - by connecting the self-service payment experience in the SAP B2B Portal with automatic reconciliation in SAP S/4HANA, closing the loop from Invoice to cash.

Technical Deep Dive

This blog will be discussed more on how the Integration works with a Solution Architecture that connects SAP B2B Self Service Portal, SAP Digital Payments Add-On (DPA) and SAP S/4HANA Cloud. 

 

 

The above high-level system architecture diagram gives us the better understanding of underlying system components and its associated Integrations with other systems 

SAP Digital Payment Addon offers variety of options to choose from that includes Payment Page (3DS), Direct App Connections and Payment by link. For the purpose of Illustration of the Implementation in this blog we have considered Payment Page(3DS) as preferable mode of implementation. 

Certain Implementation hints to be known before we proceed.

  • Please note that SAP Commerce Cloud Standard Extensions does support integration with SAP digital payment add-on but the payments are related to Cart Payments and captured against Orders but not Invoices. 
  • Try to leverage OOTB SAP Commerce cloud Extension related to SAP Digital Payments and extend it for usage of Invoice Payments. These extensions has ready to use that can reduce implementation efforts.
  • Follow the Administration Guide and User Guide to setup the SAP DPA Account setup and also the preferred PSP you have decided to be onboarded. 
  • (Disclaimer) All solution screens, configurations, and integration flows shown in this article are based on a demo environment and used for illustrative purposes only.

Now Let’s break down the flow step-by-step.

Step 1: Invoice Discovery

In the B2B Self-Service Portal (SAP Commerce Cloud), customers can view their open invoices. 

  • Invoice data is fetched in real time from S/4HANA using Standard OData services or pre-built CPI iFlows.Since B2B self service portal is a Non-Transactional System, we should prefer to use OData API services to retrieve Invoice related data.

  • The portal displays key details: invoice number, date, due amount, and status.

     

Step 2: Payment Initiation

The customer selects one or more invoices and chooses to pay the same.

  • Commerce triggers a payment request to the SAP Digital Payments Add-On (DPA) using the DPA API layer. The list of API for implementation can be found here . The Sequence diagram below gives more details on the flow. 

  • DPA handles communication with the Payment Service Provider (PSP) — e.g., Stripe, Adyen, or Worldpay — using secure, tokenized transactions.

     

     

  • Step 3: Authorization and Capture

    Once the PSP authorizes the transaction, DPA generates a payment token and transaction reference, returning it to Commerce.

    • Commerce updates the invoice status to “Payment in Progress.” and Open Invoices are immediately blocked on Portal from duplication of payments. 

    • No sensitive payment data ever touches Commerce or S/4HANA — DPA abstracts all PCI DSS compliance requirements.

    • During your implementation make sure the reference number/Invoice Id should always match with the actual Invoice ID. This will be used during Automatic Invoice Reconciliation process in S/4HANA after fetching Digital Payment Advices from PSPs.

       

  • Step 4: Posting and Reconciliation in S/4HANA

There are certain pre-requisites to be performed in SAP S/4HANA before processing Payment Advices. Managing on Virtual Bank account and setting Merchant Id Aliases are the most important aspects of this process. Please refer to the Handling Merchants Using the SAP Digital Payments which helps in performing the configurations in S/4HANA.

Reference of creating sample Virtual bank 

 

Once the payment is authorized and captured by the Payment Service Provider, the SAP Digital Payments Add-On (DPA) sends a payment advice message to SAP S/4HANA. Payment Advices are made available in DPA based on PSPs payment settlement timings. With the help of Setting Up Digital Payment Advice Processing , advices are stored in DPA and made it available to S/4HANA system during processing of Advice Processing job in SAP S/4HANA Cloud 

The flow typically follows the below path. 

Payment Advice Creation 

DPA generates a payment advice XML message containing key fields such as transaction ID, amount, currency, PSP reference, customer ID, and invoice reference. This advice is transmitted to S/4HANA via Advice Processing job in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

As discussed above in Step 3, the Invoice reference Id now plays a crucial role in determining the Open Invoice by the Auto Invoice Reconciliation process of S/4 HANA cloud. 

Below Screen is from DPA what help schedule the Job for Advice creation. Advice creations will PSP specific.

below is the screen shot of S/4 HANA cloud that shows us the reference of Job Execution for Auto Reconciliation. make sure select the right bank key, payment Method, Merchant Alias and PSP. 

Automatic Clearing:

When matching criteria are met (invoice number, customer account, payment amount), the system executes automatic clearing using standard FI-AR logic.

If partial or unmatched items exist, they remain in the payment advice queue for manual review.

once the job is successful, as the below reference screen shot we will see the success message . 

  • Step 5: Real-Time Status Visibility

Customers can immediately see that their invoice has been “Paid and Cleared” — and Finance can view the same in the AR aging report, ensuring complete alignment between customer-facing and backend systems.

Technical Components:

Layer SAP Component Role

PresentationSAP B2B Self ServiceB2B Self-Service Portal with invoice display and payment initiation
IntegrationPoint - PointOrchestration between Commerce, DPA, and S/4HANA
Payment GatewaySAP Digital Payments Add-OnSecure payment hub for PSP communication
Core ERPSAP S/4HANA Public or PCEPosting, clearing, and reconciliation of customer payments

Conclusion 

In the B2B world, digital transformation is not complete until payments are automated. By connecting SAP Commerce Cloud, SAP Digital Payments Add-On, and SAP S/4HANA, businesses can finally close the loop - achieving a true “Click-to-Cash” experience.

It’s not just about collecting payments faster - it’s about aligning customer convenience, financial accuracy, and process intelligence in one integrated flow.

entry.title: Source Data Extraction for SAP Signavio Process Intelligence using SAP Datasphere Replication Flows
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere has recently introduced the new connection type "SAP Signavio," enabling Replication Flows to replicate data directly to SAP Signavio Process Intelligence. This allows CDS Views and ABAP tables from SAP ERP systems to be replicated in a manner similar to any other replication use case in Datasphere.

On the SAP Signavio Process Intelligence side, the data will be pushed by the replication flow into the object store of the customer's Signavio workspace. A replication flow can then be mapped to a source data, providing the data from the corresponding ABAP tables and CDS Views to the Signavio ETL Pipeline to generate the process mining event log.

High-Level component overview

The diagram illustrates the complete data flow:

  • Left: Source systems (S/4HANA Public Cloud for CDS Views; S/4HANA/ECC with SLT for ABAP tables)
  • Center: SAP Datasphere orchestrates the replication flow
  • Right: SAP Signavio Process Intelligence receives data as Source Data objects
  • The dashed vertical line represents the boundary between customer landscape and internet connectivity via SAP Cloud Connector

We demonstrate now how to create a replication flow for:
(a) the customer object (CDS View i_customer) in S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition.
(b) the sales order object (ABAP tables VBAK and VBAP) in S/4HANA or SAP ECC 

Prerequisite:

  • We have a user and space in the SAP Datasphere service on BTP and have the authorization to create a new connection and to create and execute replication flows. Note that we use Replication in the pass-through option and don't require a SAP HANA as staging area within SAP Datasphere (see Replication Flow Blog series).
    We have noted down the Datasphere Tenant ID (System => About => Tenant).
  • For the replication of CDS views we have configured the integration scenario SAP_COM_0532 in our S/4 HANA Public Cloud Edition (see blog S/4HANA Public Cloud Integration with SAP Dataspehere )
  • For the replication of ABAP tables we have configured the SAP Landscape Transformation component (SLT) in our S/4HANA on-premise or use a standalone SLT system connected to our S/4 HANA system. We have enabled connectivity to the ABAP landscape via SAP Cloud Connector to SAP Datasphere (see Replicating table data from an SAP ECC system with SAP Datasphere using Replication Flows)
  • In SAP Signavio we have access to a workspace subscribed to Process Intelligence and have the authorization to perform Process Data Pipeline steps

Connectivity Handshake Signavio <-> Datasphere:

To establish a secure connection between SAP Datasphere and SAP Signavio, an OAuth Flow is required.  To do so, we start with creating an OAuth Client in our Datasphere tenant. Navigate to System => Administration and choose tab App Integration. When clicking on "Add an OAuth Client" you create your OAuth Client for Signavio. Give it a name, choose the purpose "Technical User", enter a name for the technical user to be created and assign the appropriate roles (refer to the documentation to assign the requires scoped integrator role).

Once the system has created the OAuth Client, it provides you with the OAuth credentials. Make sure to copy the credentials and note it down, you need it in the next step.

We now switch to Signavio and use the created OAuth Client to establish a secure connection. Create a "SAP Datasphere Replication Flow" connection in Signavio Process Intelligence. There is also a "SAP Datasphere" connection which relates to read the data from the SAP HANA instance in SAP Datasphere. Mind, this is not the integration flow we are looking into here and make sure to select the one with replication flow.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

In the next screen we enter the OAuth Client Credentials we have noted down earlier:

  • OAuth Client ID: Client ID you have noted down in the previous step
  • OAuth Client Secret: secret you have noted down in the previous step
  • Service Root: URL root of the Datasphere App Integration page where you create the OAuth client
  • OAuth Access Token URL: Token URL you find in the overview of the OAuth Clients in SAP Datasphere (ends with /oauth/token)

After we have created the connection in Signavio we have now established the OAuth connectivity handshake between Signavio and Datasphere and can work on a secure connection.

Let's now create the corresponding Signavio connection in Datasphere.

We logon to our SAP Datasphere instance and select our space where we create the connections and replication flows.
In the left bar menu we choose Connections and create a new connection of type Signavio. 

In the following screen we enter the connection URL of the respective Signavio landscape. In our case it is EU which is the URL https://api-mtls.eu.signavio.cloud.sap. You find the right API-Gateway endpoints in the SAP Signavio documentation for regions, IP addresses and URLs.

After entering a name for the connection we can save and validate the connection:

The Datasphere tenant is automatically mapped to the corresponding Signavio connection where we had entered the respective Datasphere tenant ID. We can not map this Datasphere tenant to another Signavio workspace unless we delete the connection in Signavio.

Replicate customer information (CDS View i_customer)

After establishing the Signavio connection we create a connection to the SAP S/4 HANA system to replicate the CDS View i_customer. We create a new connection of type S/4HANA Public Cloud:

 

We use certificate or user/password from the Communication Arrangement for Communication Scenario 0532.

Once created and validated we can continue to configure our Replication Flow for the CDS View i_customer. Choose Data Builder and new Replication Flow:

We perform the following steps to configure the source of Replication Flow:

  1. Select your S/4HANA Public Cloud as source connection
  2. Choose CDS View Extraction as source container
  3. Select CDS View I_CUSTOMER 

We configure now:

  • Load Type: Initial and Delta
  • Our recently created Signavio Connection as target
  • Content-Type "Template Type" to allow ABAP Types transformation such as Date/Time in Signavio
  • the name of the Replication Flow

Once we have saved and deployed the Replication Flow we run it. In the Integration monitor we check the status of the replication:

Once initial load is finished the delta handling will regularly replicate the changes to Signavio.

Let's now switch back to SAP Signavio Process Intelligence and create a corresponding source data. 
We crate a new source data for our new replication flow RF_Customer and assign the earlier created connection to it.

Once created we can sync the data which results in processing the data provided by the replication flow from SAP Datasphere. In particular, the initial load and possible deltas will be merged and we get the replica of the ABAP source data in Signavio. It may take some minutes depending on the size of the CDS views.

Mind, that whenever the Replication Flows send delta information a new sync is required to update the source data.

To validate the replication or use the data we have to create a Process Data Pipeline and create a SQL script. We create a new Process Data Pipeline based on a blank template and choose our source data RF_Customer.

We create a new Process Data Model with business object Customer and open the SQL Editor for a new event collector.

We can now use the preview option to validate the extraction, e.g. showing Top100 entries, count the replicated entities, etc. 

Replicate sales order information (ABAP tables VBAK and VBAP)
In the previous chapter we have successfully replicated the data from a CDS View. If we have an ABAP table to be replicated we have to leverage the SAP Landscape Transformation Server (SLT) integration to Datasphere.

Assuming we have our SLT component configured in our ABAP system (or use a dedicated SLT server) we can create a new mass transfer ID in SLT. We create it using transaction code ltrc.

Click on Create Configuration and enter the following information in the subsequent screens:

  • Configuration Name and Description
  • RFC Destination and (optionally) Read from Single Client flag
  • SAP Data Intelligence (Replication Management Service) under Other in Target System
  • Job options (we may start with 1 job first)

We have finished our SLT preparation step. All following replication configurations (tables, fields, filters, etc.) will now be configured in the Replication Flow in Datasphere which will be then pushed down to your SLT configuration. Let's switch to our Datasphere tenant and create a new connection to our SLT instance. 

When creating a new connection choose SAP ABAP as system type:

  • Protocol: RFC
  • Connection Type: Application Server (or Message Server if you prefer)
  • Application Server, System Number and Client
  • Choose Cloud Connector to allow on-premise connectivity
  • Authentication Type: for user/password choose your ABAP user for SLT with appropriate roles

We can save and validate our new connection.

 

Once connection is established, we create a new Replication Flow for our ABAP table replication. Create the replication flow similar to the CDS View, but use SLT as source container:

  • Business Name: RF_SalesOrder
  • Source Connection: our SLT connection
  • Source Container: "SLT - SAP LT Replication Server"
    • our mass transfer ID from the ABAP system
  • Source Objects: ABAP Tables VBAK and VBAP 
  • Load Type: Initial and Delta
  • Content Type: Template Type
  • (optional): add a projection to filter the data or reduce the number of fields
  • Target Connection: your Signavio connection (same as used for CDS View replication)

Optionally you may add filters or field projections which will be pushed down to SLT and reduces the data volume to be transferred.

Save, Deploy and run the replication flow. To monitor the transfer you can choose Data Integration Monitor in Datasphere and the monitoring tool in SLT. Data will be gathered by SLT and Datasphere can then pull the data to Datasphere and directly forward it to Signavio.

You see the replication status of each table and some metrics on the replication run, e.g. 886.757 entries from VBAK had bee initially replicated in 5:12 minutes using 9 partitions, 3 delta updates have been already executed.

Once data is replicated the Replication flow will show status "Active (retrying objects)" as we have chosen Initial and Delta Mode. The Replication Flow continuously checks for updates in the ABAP Tables and replicate them to Signavio.

Let's switch to Signavio and create a corresponding source data for our replication flow for the sales order ABAP Table.

We have selected the same Datasphere connection as we have used for the CDS Views, and the RF_SalesOrder replication flow.

In the following screen we sync the replication flow. 

Once the sync is being processed we can see the tables VBAK and VBAP alongside with the sync log.

 

With having the source data prepared for further processing we can now create a Process Data Pipeline to generate the process mining event log.

In our pipeline we crate a new business object SalesOrder and create the SQL scripts for case and event collectors. As an example we create the event collector "create sales order".

We've demonstrated how to leverage SAP Datasphere to replicate and synchronize data from source systems using Replication Flow. Give this method a try and share your results and experiences in the comments below!

entry.title: New Kyma Telemetry Docs: Simplified, Task-Oriented, and User-First
entry.content:
We're happy to announce the release of the completely restructured and rewritten documentation for the Kyma Telemetry module! We've moved from a component-centric view to a user-first, task-oriented structure, all centered around a new, unified Telemetry Pipeline API.

 

What's New for Our Users?

  • The Unified Telemetry Pipeline API – At the heart of the new structure is the Telemetry Pipeline API. With the introduction of OTLP-based LogPipelines, you can now use a consistent set of CRDs to configure all your telemetry signals, which reduces complexity and makes your setup easier to maintain.

  • A Clearer, Task-Based Structure – Find what you need faster with new top-level guides for Collecting Logs, Collecting Traces, and Collecting Metrics. Each guide walks you through the process for a specific signal, from minimal setup to advanced configuration

  • A Clear Migration Path – If you're still using the legacy Fluent Bit (HTTP) log output, read Migrate Your LogPipeline From HTTP to OTLP, which guides you step-by-step to switch to the new OTLP setup without data loss.

The 'Why' Behind the Change: A Look at the Craft

If you're a fellow tech writer or just curious about the why, this wasn't just a rewrite; it was a fundamental shift in our information architecture:

Our previous documentation was component-centric. It described each component (Telemetry Manager, gateways, agents, pipelines...) and its internal architecture, explaining "What does the component do?". Based on that, the reader had to figure out how to accomplish a task.

Our new approach is goal-oriented, built on principles from the DITA (Darwin Information Typing Architecture) and industry best practices. Our guiding question is "What is the user trying to achieve?" This led us to structure the content as self-contained pages, each focusing on a user goal. For readers interested in the nitty-gritty details - you still find all of those in the consolidated Architecture docs.

Why This Matters

This new structure makes it easier to see what's common and what's different for the Telemetry pipeline types. Furthermore, we've re-centered the documentation on the actions you need to perform:

  • Start with your goal: Task-oriented titles such as Monitor Pipeline Health help you find what you need without knowing our internal component names.
  • Progressive disclosure of information: Get started with a minimal configuration quickly, and then explore advanced operations like filtering or processing only when you need them.
  • Get straight to the point: With consolidated troubleshooting instructions on the top level, you can start start fixing issues immediately without reading through unrelated details.

Get Started Today

We invite you to dive into the new Telemetry module documentation. We're proud of this new structure and believe it's a clear step up for clarity and usability.

Your Feedback Matters

Whether you're a user of the module or a fellow writer, we'd love to hear your thoughts. Give us feedback directly on the SAP Help Portal pages. Your input is crucial as we continue to evolve our content.

entry.title: Re: Location mapping in Recruiting Marketing
entry.content:
Hi @Nim_18 ,

When you use the Location Object on the Job Requisition, the Location field stores an object reference (Location GUID), not the display name.
Even though you see the “Name” in the Recruiting UI, RMK feeds don’t automatically resolve it to the display name unless that specific location field is mapped as a string field in CSB > Job Field Mapping.

Solution : Use a Custom String Field

  1. Create a custom field in the Job Requisition (e.g.,customLocationName)

  2. Make it a standard string field type.

  3. Add a Business Rule that auto-populates this custom field with the Location.name whenever the req is created.

Rule Sample
Event: On Save
IF: Location is not empty
THEN: Set customLocationName=Location.name

  1. Map customLocationName to the feed field in

Hope this helps!! Let me know if you need any help

Thanks,

kr,

karthick.

entry.title: How to Integrate SAP BTP Cloud Logging Service with SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) Using SAML
entry.content:
Introduction

  • Why this matters: SAP Cloud Logging (based on OpenSearch) supports SAML 2.0 integration for secure access and role-based authorization using IAS Groups.
    In this SAP Help, it's not mentioned about setups regarding IAS Side. That's why I wrote this article.
    https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-logging/cloud-logging/prerequisites
  • Benefits:
    • Centralized identity management
    • Single Sign-On (SSO)
    • Compliance with SAP BTP security recommendations (BTP-CLS-0001)
  • Prerequisites:
    • A Cloud Logging Service instance in SAP BTP
    • An active SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) tenant

Step 1: Prepare IAS for SAML Integration

  1. Log in to IAS Admin Console: https://[tenant].accounts.ondemand.com/admin
  2. Create a new SAML 2.0 Application:
    • Application Name: CloudLogging-CLS-Test

  3. Add SAML 2.0 Configuration:
    • Configure Manually

    • SP Entity ID: cls-test
    • ACS URL: https://[cls-url]/_opendistro/_security/saml/acs
      (Please get this ACS URL from CLS instance "dashboards-endpoint")
    • Single Logout URL: https://[cls-url]
    • Binding: HTTP_REDIRECT

    • NameID Format: Email

  4. Configure Attributes:
    • Name: groups
    • Source: Identity Directory
    • Value: All Groups

Step 2: Create IAS Group for Admin Access

  • Group Name: LoggingAdmins
  • Assign users who need administrative access to Cloud Logging.

Step 3: Generate Signing Key and Certificate (Optional)

You can skip this step. If you enable signed authentication requests in IAS:

openssl req -x509 -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout private.key -out cert.pem -nodes -days 365
openssl pkcs8 -topk8 -v1 PBE-SHA1-3DES -in private.key -out private_pkcs8.key
base64 -w0 private_pkcs8.key > private_pkcs8.b64
  • Upload cert.pem to IAS.
  • Use the Base64-encoded private key in Cloud Logging configuration.

Step 4: Configure Cloud Logging Service

Create a JSON file (saml-config.json😞

{
  "saml": {
    "enabled": true,
    "initiated": true,
    "idp": {
      "metadata_url": "https://<IAS-tenant>/saml2/metadata",
      "entity_id": "https://<IAS-tenant>"
    },
    "admin_group": "LoggingAdmins",
    "roles_key": "groups",
    "sp": {
      "entity_id": "cls-test",
      "signature_private_key": "<Base64-encoded-key>", //Optional
      "signature_private_key_password": "<password>" //Optional
    },
    "exchange_key": "RandomKey32CharsRandomKey32Chars"
  }
}

Apply the configuration:

cf update-service cls-test -c saml-config.json

Step 5: Validate the Integration

  • Open the Cloud Logging Dashboard URL: https://[your-cls-url]
  • Confirm redirection to IAS login.
  • Log in with a user from LoggingAdmins group.
  • Verify OpenSearch roles (all_access) are mapped correctly.

Troubleshooting

  • 400 Bad Request: Check ACS URL and SP Entity ID match IAS settings.
  • 401 Unauthorized: Verify group attribute mapping and signature settings.
  • Disable SAML if needed:
cf update-service cls-test -c '{"saml":{"enabled":false}}'

Conclusion

  • SAML integration ensures secure, centralized authentication for Cloud Logging.
  • IAS provides flexibility for role-based access and SSO.
  • Always use strong passwords and manage certificates securely.

entry.title: Navigating the SAP Learning Help Center: Your Gateway to Seamless Learning Support!
entry.content:
Embarking on a journey through SAP’s extensive ecosystem can be both exciting and challenging. Whether you’re an experienced professional looking to enhance your skills or a newcomer eager to explore SAP’s offerings, having dependable support is essential. That’s where the SAP Learning Help Center comes in—a comprehensive resource designed to support learners at every step of their SAP learning journey.

 

This centralized portal offers a wide range of resources, including step-by-step guides, troubleshooting advice, and detailed FAQs, all aimed at improving your learning experience. From onboarding assistance to resolving technical issues, the Help Center is your one-stop destination for reliable support.

Before submitting a support ticket, please take a moment to explore our Help Center resources for quick answers and solutions

In this blog, we will explore the key features of the SAP Learning Help Center, highlight common scenarios where learners seek assistance, and share tips on how to make the most of this valuable resource.

 

Common Scenarios for Creating a Support Case with the Learning Team:

You may need to open a support case in the following situations:

  1. Difficulty scheduling exams
  2. Requests to update names on existing certificates
  3. Questions regarding subscription or renewal processes
  4. Seeking guidance on choosing the right certification path
  5. Issues related to student subscription accounts

 

How to Create a Case with the Learning Team

To create a support case, please follow these steps:                 

Visit the SAP Learning Help Center.

 

Select Create a new case or check the status of an existing one.

 

Click on Create a case, which will open the SAP Learning Self Service(s) page.

Click Create Case again to open the form, then fill in the required details:

    • Subject
    • Service Category
    • Description
    • Email of affected user (optional)
    • Attach any relevant files (if applicable)

Submit the form.

 

 

Once submitted, your case will be created, and you will receive an email notification linked to your S-User ID with the case details.

Additional Resources:

  • Knowledge Base Article (KBA): 2404504 - How to get help with the SAP Learning Hub or SAP Training Center - SAP for Me
  • Points of Contact | SAP Community

 Thanks for reading!

We hope you found this helpful. Please note that the Customer Interaction Center is always happy to guide you on any of the mentioned processes and assist you with any queries you may have!

We would love to hear from you, let us know what you think?

Read more Customer Interaction Center blog posts Here!

 If you have any questions, please feel free to ask us in the Q&A All Questions in Customer Experience | SAP Community and All Questions in Support Services | SAP Community

entry.title: Incorrect purchase info record unit migration by Migration cockpit
entry.content: During create Purchase Info Records with conditions by using the Migration Cockpit, an incorrect unit was migrated for specific condition types. The correct unit is %, but migrated as USD. So the amount became very large. eg. The same Combination of "material+ supplier+ purchasing organization+ plant" have 2 condition types: Y001: Gross Price [USD]; Y051: Duty [%] When using migration cockpit, Y051 amount incorrect migrated as 97568%. This has led to two issues. The first is incorrect data migration, which needs to be corrected to the right data. The second is that in the template, the Condition Sequence Number field is written as 1 and 2 , means including two different conditions: Y001 and Y051. However, in the system, the purchase condition record number in the KONP table for Y001 and Y051 is the same, but the item number is different. In the A017 table, the condition record number only has the condition type Y001.This results in the inability to open the Y051 detail page when viewing the purchase information record with ME13. However, when create a purchase order and standard cost estimate, the condition records of Y001 and Y051 can be automatically set in. Who can tell us how to modify the errors caused by unit errors and multiple condition types?

entry.title: UNTECO via Program Not Updating RESB Table (Unlike COR2 Standard Log)
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We are trying to reverse TECO (UNTECO) for a process order programmatically.

We are currently using the FM STATUS_CHANGE_INTERN to change the order status from TECO back to REL.
While this successfully updates the system status (JEST), it does not update the dependent tables, especially RESB, which remains with the deletion indicator ( XLOEK='X' ).
In the standard transaction COR2 → Cancel Technical Completion, SAP automatically reactivates the reservations (clears XLOEK) — this does not happen when using the FM.

We have already tried the following options:

  1. BAP_RESERVATION_CHANGE
    → Returns the message “Reservations automatically created. No manual changes possible.”
    Hence, we cannot use this for order-generated reservations.

  2. BDC for COR2
    → As per SAP Note 2729700, COR2 is not batch-recordable, so BDC is not an option.

Our goal is to achieve the same effect as COR2 → Cancel TECO, i.e.,

  • Reverse TECO status, and

  • Automatically clear the deletion indicator in RESB (and other dependent updates).

Has anyone implemented an alternative approach or identified an internal FM/BAPI that replicates COR2’s Cancel Technical Completion logic in a custom program?

Any guidance or standard FM suggestion would be appreciated.

Thanks & Regards,
Vineeth Nekkanti
SAP ABAP Developer
